image.altText: A woman stands in front of media microphones with the Australian, NT and Aboriginal flags behind her.

props.synopsis: Less than 48 hours since the Country Liberal Party's landslide election victory in the Northern Territory, the incoming chief minister has revealed her government's first actions to overturn crime and "restore community safety".

title.children: 'The important work has begun': NT chief minister-elect outlines new government's first steps

image.altText: A middle-aged, dark-haired man wearing a broad-brimmed hat.

props.synopsis: Tributes are pouring in for Luke Bowen, the former chief executive of the NT Cattlemen's Association, who steered the sector through the 2011 live export crisis.

title.children: Cattle sector mourns loss of the 'greatest advocate' the industry 'ever had'

image.altText: Lia and Eva election night composite 2

props.synopsis: Eye-watering debt, entrenched Indigenous disadvantage and a public at its wit's end with high rates of crime spell a tough four years ahead for incoming chief minister Lia Finocchiaro and her new-look team.

title.children: A political earthquake has shattered the NT's Labor party, leaving the CLP with a monumental task ahead

image.altText: two men hugging, while one carries his daughter on his hip

props.synopsis: The NT polls have closed and the results show a resounding victory for the Country Liberal Party, but there's also been some interesting swings to the Greens and independents. Here's how each electorate voted.

title.children: Breaking down the NT election outcome: How the results fell in every seat across the territory

image.altText: John Setka sitting behind a number of microphones at a Melbourne media conference.

props.synopsis: Mr Setka claims former Workplace Relations Minister Tony Burke agreed to forgo appointing administrators to the CFMEU in exchange for the union boss's resignation.

title.children: PM says former union boss's claim he was left 'trembling' after elevator conversation is 'nonsense'

image.altText: Justin Stein

props.synopsis: Justin Laurens Stein is jailed for life without parole for the murder of schoolgirl. The nine-year-old's body was put in a barrel and dumped near the Colo River, south-west of Sydney, in January 2022.

title.children: Justin Stein jailed for life without parole over schoolgirl's 'callous' murder

image.altText: portrait of Hajj Mohammad Hamieh by Ron Foley ABC

props.synopsis: Hezbollah and Israel's war is escalating. Four Corners travelled to Lebanon's Hezbollah heartland and found a group determined to hit back.

title.children: Where Hajj Mohamad lives, Hezbollah is everywhere. But he's not afraid to speak his mind

image.altText: Police tape stretched over a suburban road. A police paddy wagon and van are parked nearby.

props.synopsis: Police are investigating after 29-year-old underworld figure Tarek Ayoub was shot and killed in the car park of a Parramatta unit complex on Monday morning. Mr Ayoub, who was known in underworld circles as the "Angel of Death", was visiting an associate, according to police.

title.children: 'Lived by the sword and died by the sword': Sydney underworld figure killed in execution-style murder

image.altText: Woman holding a young toddler.

props.synopsis: Months after Australian aid worker Zomi Frankcom was killed in an Israeli air strike, her brother Mal sits down with 7.30 to discuss the missing pieces of the puzzle the Israeli government still has not shared.

title.children: Inside the hour of misery that changed the lives of the Frankcom family

image.altText: A digital board with multiple rows reading "cancelled".

props.synopsis: A long-awaited blueprint for the aviation sector has been handed down, with a promise to establish a charter of rights for customers to seek cash refunds when their flights are cancelled or unreasonably delayed.

title.children: Australians will be able to get cash refunds for delayed and cancelled flights under government crackdown

image.altText: Peter Garrett sings into a microphone on stage, dressed in a blue shirt under colourful orange and red lights.

props.synopsis: The Melbourne Symphony Orchestra's managing director has left the organisation, amid controversy over the orchestra's handling of a pianist's onstage comments about the war in Gaza.

title.children: Peter Garrett to investigate Melbourne Symphony Orchestra in wake of controversial handling of pianist's Gaza comments

image.altText: A close up of a man with blonde hair smiling with his dog on a porch.

props.synopsis: The right to disconnect means you can reasonably refuse to be contacted outside of work hours. For people tied to the 'digital leash' of phones and email this marks a substantial boost in their right to break free.

title.children: You have the right to disconnect from work after hours from today. But what does that mean in practice?

image.altText: Surfers and swimmers in the water at Bondi Beach in calm conditions.

props.synopsis: It's winter in Australia, but as you've probably noticed, the weather is unusually warm. The top temperatures over large parts of the country this weekend were well above average for this time of year.

title.children: 40 degrees in August? A climate expert explains why it's ridiculously hot right now

image.altText: Grey dirt gives way to a dark crevice, with blue and white streaks of ice seen above.

props.synopsis: The cave, located at the Breiðamerkurjökull glacier, collapsed as a group of 25 tourists were visiting the site on a tour.

title.children: Icelandic ice cave collapse leaves one tourist dead and two missing

image.altText: Jumps racing

props.synopsis: Racing Victoria has conceded its "safety record regressed" in the 2024 jumps racing season after three horses had to be euthanased on a single day of racing at Ballarat.

title.children: 'Deadly day' at Victorian regional race meeting sees three horses put down and two jockeys injured

image.altText: Novak Djokovic looks at the ball

props.synopsis: After claiming Olympic gold, Novak Djokovic has won everything there is to win in tennis. But he is still confident of making even more history at the US Open in a wide-open tournament.

title.children: Novak Djokovic aims 'to make more history' at US Open

image.altText: Stephen Crichton looks down

props.synopsis: The NRL has rejected claims there is confusion around high tackles, adamant that the error not to sin-bin Stephen Crichton in round 25 is largely an isolated one.

title.children: NRL hits back at inconsistency claims after high-shot confusion

image.altText: A man in a suit stands to speak to parliament.

props.synopsis: Tasmania's deputy premier, Michael Ferguson resigns as infrastructure minister over the bungled rollout of the new Spirit of Tasmania vessels.

title.children: 'I truly tried to keep the project on track': Ferguson resigns over Spirit of Tasmania debacle

image.altText: A man with grey hair and beard leans over bushfire bunker built into ground

props.synopsis: An Adelaide Hills father installed a six-person bushfire bunker at his property after the 2019 Cudlee Creek bushfire, without first seeking planning approvals — now, the council have issued a removal notice — a decision which he is appealing.

title.children: Daniel Katz installed a 'last resort' bunker after fleeing a bushfire. He's been told to remove it

image.altText: Yellow billboard next to busy street

props.synopsis: The Jacqui Lambie Network's implosion in Tasmania follows a growing list of Australian namesake parties that have quickly encountered turbulence.

title.children: Does the Lambie implosion show that 'personality politics' is doomed to fail?

image.altText: A man in a blue suit and red tie and a woman in a camel-coloured suit and white shirt

props.synopsis: Americans remain deeply polarised over their choice between Kamala Harris or Donald Trump in November's presidential election. In Australia, a new survey suggests one candidate has overwhelming support.

title.children: Harris or Trump? If Australians were voting, the result would be a landslide

props.synopsis: A senator is calling for the government to end its long-standing relationship with South Korea's Eastern Social Welfare Society after a Background Briefing investigation revealed the agency falsified documents in historical adoption cases, dating back to the 1980s.

title.children: 'A demand for orphans': Senator calls for end to Korean adoptions

image.altText: A blue car with crash damage sits on the road. Police tape surrounds the scene.

props.synopsis: Police have charged Antony Benson with multiple offences after he allegedly stabbed a woman and crashed a car at Engadine in Sydney's south.

title.children: Man charged after allegedly stabbing woman while driving in Sydney's south

image.altText: A stock trader looks down at a tablet as he works on the floor of a busy stock exchange while surrounded by screens.

props.synopsis: The ASX200 closed higher, with health insurer nib being punished despite a 67 per cent increase in profit. It comes after US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell's comments about cutting rates lifted global markets on Friday. Look back at the day's events.

title.children: ASX closes higher as NIB shares dumped despite profit increase — as it happened

image.altText: Driver Sang Van Huynh with a cap and glasses walks outside court

props.synopsis: A truck driver who ran a red light and hit two 16-year-old Adelaide high school students, shattering the "dreams and aspirations" of one who was left with a brain injury, is ordered to do community service but has avoided jail.

title.children: Truck driver who ran red light outside school and hit students gets suspended sentence

image.altText: Telegram founder Pavel Durov

props.synopsis: The founder of encrypted messaging service Telegram has been detained in France as part of an investigation into a lack of moderation and criminal use of the platform.

title.children: Telegram's CEO Pavel Durov has been arrested. Here's what to know about the app and its founder

image.altText: A middle-aged, dark-haired man wearing a broad-brimmed hat.

props.synopsis: Tributes are pouring in for Luke Bowen, the former chief executive of the NT Cattlemen's Association, who steered the sector through the 2011 live export crisis.

title.children: Cattle sector mourns loss of the 'greatest advocate' the industry 'ever had'

image.altText: Hawthorn v Western Bulldogs

props.synopsis: The Hawks will play their first Friday night game in two years, after the AFL confirmed the week one schedule for the 2024 finals series.

title.children: AFL releases finals fixture as league heavyweights get their first Friday night clash in two years

image.altText: A 17th-century classical painting, showing a woman, arms outstretched, and a mostly naked man lying in front of her.

props.synopsis: When conservators at the National Gallery of Victoria X-rayed a 17th-century artwork, they discovered a strange swirl in the right-hand corner. A little investigation ultimately revealed a hidden painting.

title.children: The secrets in this 17th-century artwork were discovered when its X-ray was flipped upside down

image.altText: Photo of smiling man with black jumper and beard.

props.synopsis: Giuliano Pirone collapsed in a shower after an early morning session at a Perth 24-hour gym and was only found that night after his mother raised the alarm.

title.children: Bodybuilder in coma after collapsing in gym shower and left undiscovered for 15 hours with water running

image.altText: Selfie portrait of a bearded man in helmet and bullet-proof vest

props.synopsis: A British safety adviser working with a team of journalists is dead after a Russian missile struck a hotel in the Ukrainian city of Kramatorsk.

title.children: Reuters safety adviser killed and two journalists injured in strike on Ukrainian hotel

image.altText: Woman with black dress and long wavy hair leans forward

props.synopsis: Michelle Brasier was told she had a 97 per cent chance of getting cancer. She chose to laugh about it.

title.children: If you could find out whether you were going to die young, would you?

image.altText: A billboard shows a smiling woman in colourful dress, and welcomes people to the 53rd Pacific Islands Forum.

props.synopsis: Pacific leaders are once again preparing for the Pacific Island Forum, the biggest meeting of the year, where they will gather and discuss some of the most pressing and complex issues facing the region.

title.children: In Tonga's sprawling archipelago, a meeting of Pacific leaders could reshape the region
